brief_description: Systems biology study to determine the molecular hallmarks of naturally acquired clinical immunity to Plasmodium falciparum (Pf) malaria using multi-omic datasets (including RNA-seq transcriptomics, Pf antigen microarray, multi-parameter flow cytometry, multiplex cytokine analysis) in a cohort of Malian children who underwent active bi-weekly surveillance during an intense 6-month malaria transmission season.
description: Immunity to malaria can be acquired through natural exposure to Plasmodium falciparum (Pf), but only after years of repeated infections. Typically, this immunity is acquired by adolescence and confers protection against disease, but Pf infection per se. Efforts to understand the mechanisms of this immunity are integral to the development of a vaccine that would mimic the induction of adult immunity in children. The current study applies systems biology approaches to a cohort from the rural village of Kalifabougou, Mali, where Pf transmission is intense and seasonal. Signatures that correlate with protection from malaria may yield new hypotheses regarding the biological mechanisms through which malaria immunity is induced by natural Pf infection. The resulting datasets will be of considerable value in the urgent worldwide effort to develop a malaria vaccine that could prevent more than a million deaths annually.
endpoints: Weekly active surveillance visits and passive case detection of acute malaria episodes to determine time from Pf blood-stage infection to febrile malaria.
hypothesis: Distinct molecular signatures in peripheral blood can differentiate children who are protected from malarial symptoms after documented Pf blood-stage infection from those who progressed to fever once infected.
objectives: Identify molecular signatures in peripheral blood that best predict protection from febrile malaria using a systems biology approach.

arm.description: Sample of n = 80 Malian children and young adults age 3 months to 25 years old, selected from a larger cohort of 695 subjects initially enrolled in the study
